items.standfirst: Follow live as we bring you the news from Australia and beyond.
items.content: Follow live as we bring you the news from Australia and beyond.

items.title: ‘Wrong kind of sorry’: Qantas hit with $90m penalty for illegally sacking 1800 workers
items.standfirst: Justice Michael Lee ordered that $50 million be paid directly to the Transport Workers’ Union as part of the largest fine under workplace law in Australian corporate history.
items.content: Justice Michael Lee ordered that $50 million be paid directly to the Transport Workers’ Union as part of the largest fine under workplace law in Australian corporate history.

items.title: Qantas fined $90 million for illegally sacking staff
items.standfirst: Australia's largest airline has been ordered to pay a landmark penalty of $90 million.
items.content: Australia's largest airline has been ordered to pay a landmark penalty of $90 million for what has been dubbed the largest case of illegal sackings in the country's history.Qantas outsourced more than 1800 baggage handlers, cleaners and ground staff in 2020, in a move the Federal Court ruled was designed to curb union bargaining power in wage negotiations.The embattled airline's appeal to the High Court was unsuccessful, paving the way for the penalty to be awarded on Monday.READ MORE: Four cars including $1 million Ferrari stolen from Melbourne homeThe Transport Workers Union sought the maximum penalty of $121 million, while Qantas urged Justice Michael Lee to impose a "mid-range" penalty between $40 million and $80 million.The Federal Court judge cited the "sheer scale of the contraventions, being the largest of their type" as a reason to impose a penalty that would deter other businesses from similar conduct.He ordered Qantas to pay $90 million in penalties, $50 million of which is to be paid directly to the union that brought the proceedings and highlighted the illegal conduct."To deprive someone of work illegally is to deprive someone of an aspect of their human dignity, and this is not assuaged simply by expressions of regret," Justice Lee said.READ MORE: Man charged after father, son, killed going for ice cream in Queensland He was scathing about the embattled airline's conduct after the outsourcing, pointing to efforts to place a "less than candid" picture of the outsourcing decision before the court.He noted Qantas had apologised publicly but then had attempted to deny any compensation payments to the affected workers.Qantas will have to pay the hefty bill on top of a $120 million compensation payment it has made to the affected ground staff for their economic loss, pain and suffering following the outsourcing.However, Justice Lee said he didn't have enough evidence to be convinced those payments would be made.The court was told the scandal-plagued airline began to finally accept responsibility for its actions in 2023, Justice Lee noted, which coincided with the departure of former CEO Alan Joyce.The courtroom was packed with union members and representatives, who hugged and exchanged smiles after Justice Lee handed down his decision.It comes after Qantas also sold tickets to cancelled flights for several years, triggering more legal turmoil and a $100 million fine after it was sued by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: 'Wrong kind of sorry': Qantas fined $90 million for illegally outsourcing jobs
items.standfirst: The airline giant will face a $90 million penalty over its decision to illegally outsource more than 1,800 ground handling jobs during the COVID pandemic.
items.content: The airline giant will face a $90 million penalty over its decision to illegally outsource more than 1,800 ground handling jobs during the COVID pandemic.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Qantas was ordered to pay a $90 million penalty for illegally outsourcing ground handling jobs.
• The fine is the largest under Australian workplace law in corporate history.
• The airline illegally outsourced over 1,800 ground handling jobs during the COVID pandemic.
• Justice Michael Lee ordered $50 million be paid to the Transport Workers’ Union.
• The penalty follows a decision to sack workers, which was deemed unlawful.

clusters.title: Surfer's 'miracle' escape as shark snaps board in two at NSW beach
clusters.neutral_headline: Surfer Has Narrow Escape After Shark Bites Board
bullet_summary: P hotos showed the surfer holding his broken board on the beach at Cabarita with a large bite missing from it
Reported by ABC News Australia, 9News, The Age

items.title: Surfer's 'miracle' escape as shark snaps board in two at NSW beach
items.standfirst: A surfer sitting on his board was attacked early this morning on the New South Wales north coast.
items.content: A surfer sitting on his board was attacked early this morning on the New South Wales north coast.

items.title: 'Insane': Surfer's miracle escape from huge shark at NSW beach
items.standfirst: P hotos showed the surfer holding his broken board on the beach at Cabarita with a large bite missing from it.
items.content: A surfer has had a narrow escape from a shark in northern NSW.Footage caught on a surf camera at Cabarita Beach at 7.26am today and shared on the Instagram page "18 Seconds" shows a surfer in the water alongside a dark shape, before splashing.A photo posted on the account shows a surfer in a wetsuit standing with a surfboard broken in two, with what appears to be a huge bite taken out of it. READ MORE: Major manhunt after deadly double shooting outside Sydney pubFootage posted on Facebook also shows the surfer standing with the remains of the board on the beach, as a friend comes and hugs him. Kim Maree shared the video and said: "A bit of drama on the beach after I filmed the beautiful sunrise. Another shark attack".The NSW Shark Smart account confirmed a "reported shark incident at Norries Head Beach, Cabarita".READ MORE: Extraordinary move ahead of Zelenskyy, Trump meeting Surf website Beach Grit names the surfer as Brad Ross.Local reports say a great white shark was spotted by a drone soon after. Cabarita Beach is south of Kingscliff, just south of the NSW-Queensland border. Surfing great Kelly Slater expressed his disbelief about the lucky escape."How does it bite that much and miss the guy? Insane!" he wrote in an Instagram comment.The beach has been closed by the local council. READ MORE: Capital set for soaking as another cold front sweeps in

items.title: ‘Insane!’ Surfer has miracle escape after shark takes bite out of board
items.standfirst: Surfing legend Kelly Slater even weighed in on the near miss at a popular northern NSW beach, which has recorded two shark incidents in as many months.
items.content: Surfing legend Kelly Slater even weighed in on the near miss at a popular northern NSW beach, which has recorded two shark incidents in as many months.

clusters.ai_summary:
• A surfer was attacked by a shark on the New South Wales north coast.
• The shark snapped the surfer's board in two during the incident.
• Photos show the surfer holding his broken board on the beach.
• The incident occurred at Cabarita Beach, a popular surfing location.
• Surfing legend Kelly Slater commented on the near miss.

items.title: Three charged after Melbourne dad allegedly attacked with machete
items.standfirst: Three people have been charged after a Melbourne father was allegedly stabbed with a machete while trying to fight against a gang who broke into his home.
items.content: Three people have been charged after a Melbourne father was allegedly stabbed with a machete while trying to fight against a gang who broke into his home.

items.title: Charges after father stabbed 11 times in alleged Kew East home invasion
items.standfirst: A man and two teenagers have been charged after a husband, wife and grandparents were hurt during an alleged confrontation inside the Melbourne home.
items.content: A man and two teenagers have been charged after a husband, wife and grandparents were hurt during an alleged confrontation inside the Melbourne home.

items.title: Three charged after Melbourne dad allegedly stabbed 11 times
items.standfirst: A man and two teens have been charged after a Melbourne father was allegedly stabbed multiple times while trying to fight against a gang who allegedly broke into his Kew East home.
items.content: Three people have been charged after a Melbourne father was allegedly stabbed with a machete while trying to fight against a gang who broke into his home in Kew East.Police claim the 39-year-old man's wife was forced into a separate room with their two sleeping toddlers as the group sped off in the couple's car.Two teenage boys, aged 16 and 17, along with a 24-year-old man have all been charged with multiple offences in relation to the incident, including false imprisonment, aggravated home invasion and intentionally cause serious injury.READ MORE: Light plane crash lands on Sydney golf course The "awful" incident even left senior detectives shaken."I've never seen anything like this, this is awful," Victoria Police's Leeanne Trusler said."There's nothing to indicate it being premeditated, they've just chosen this house and destroyed a family."The gang of five arrived on Oxford Street just before 4am today.Allegedly armed with a knife and machete, they used garden shears from the shed to smash a window.Once inside, they forced the husband and wife into separate rooms and allegedly stabbed the 39-year-old man 11 times. He was taken to hospital with a fractured arm, cuts to his face and will need to undergo eye surgery.READ MORE: Ratepayers have named the best local councils in Australia His parents, aged 69 and 70, were allegedly also cut and bruised as they tried to help."They're not used to people fighting back, and this home owner fought back," Trusler said."It's gotta stop. This has got to stop. Someone is going to be seriously hurt. Well, someone has now been seriously hurt. It's beyond a joke."His two kids, just two and three years old, thankfully slept through the attack.Their 34-year-old mother was treated for minor injuries while their nanny was uninjured.Police say four of the offenders got into the victim's BMW, while the fifth offender allegedly left in the vehicle they arrived in. Two males who are believed to have been involved in the incident remain on the run."Aggravated burglaries, that have got to one every hour across the state are now getting to the stage they are so violent that we've now seen a father stabbed with his children at home and each and every Victorian will feel that today," Victoria's Opposition Leader Brad Battin said.The 24-year-old Caroline Springs man was remanded to appear at Melbourne Magistrates' Court in November.The 17-year-old from the Frankston area and the 16-year-old also from the Caroline Springs area were both remanded to appear at a children's court at a later date.Anyone who witnessed the incident, has CCTV/dashcam footage or any information that could assist police is urged to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000 or submit a confidential report online.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Three people have been charged following a home invasion in Melbourne.
• A father was allegedly stabbed multiple times with a machete.
• The incident occurred when the father tried to fight off a gang.
• The alleged attack happened in the father's Kew East home.
• A man and two teenagers have been charged in connection to the incident.

clusters.title: Crime group 'links' in spotlight after deadly Sydney pub shooting
clusters.neutral_headline: Police Investigate Sydney Pub Shooting, One Dead

items.title: Crime group 'links' in spotlight after deadly Sydney pub shooting
items.standfirst: Police believe the attack, which left one man dead and another badly injured, was targeted.
items.content: Police are investigating organised crime links after one man was shot dead and another seriously injured outside a pub in Sydney's inner west yesterday evening.Detectives are doorknocking neighbours to find out more about the deadly attack at the Harold Park Hotel on Ross Street, Forest Lodge, after the shooting was reported at about 6.40pm on Sunday.Officers arrived to find two men shot multiple times by an assailant who fled the scene and is now at large, sparking a major search.READ MORE: Businesses devastated after suspected firebombing in BrisbaneThe two men had been watching UFC 319 onscreen at the pub, before leaving to go to their car.Detective Superintendent Alfio Sergi told media this morning that the fatally shot man, aged 39, had died near the car on Wigram Street.The second man, aged 31, was shot while running for his life back towards the pub, and was found "slumped over a garbage bin" in Alfred Road. Both men suffered multiple gunshot wounds, with NSW Ambulance paramedics treating them at the scene.A passing doctor provided first aid to the man who had been shot first, but was unable to save him.The other, who had wounds to the neck, chest and abdomen, was taken to Royal Prince Alfred Hospital in a serious condition.Medical students in the Harold Park Hotel helped provide first aid to him, along with paramedics. Sergi said at this early stage police believed there had only been one shooter, but they weren't discounting the possibility of an accomplice.He was unwilling to speculate on motive, but said he believed it was a "targeted attack"."Obviously (we are) looking at links with organised crime networks, that'll be the focus of our investigation," he said.The injured man had this morning undergone a second round of surgery, and police have not yet been able to speak with him.Anybody with daschcam footage of the area between 2pm and 7pm is urged to come forward. Witnesses reported hearing between six and 12 gunshots with multiple bullet casings found by police at the scene."I walked around the corner, I saw the guy had been, they'd been shot," one bystander told 9News."One of them had been shot, was lying on the ground."So I ran up to him and then 30 seconds later, some doctors and some other ladies that were inside the hotel came out."One local told the Sydney Morning Herald she saw one of the men shot about six times."He had been shot multiple times, at least six times," she said."But he was still conscious, and they put him in the ambulance so hopefully he makes a full recovery."It just doesn't feel like something that happens in Sydney very often, but when it does happen, it feels pretty scary."Among patrons in the busy pub were at least one doctor and nurse who rushed to offer first aid before multiple ambulance and police cars swarmed the scene. The pub's manager told the Sydney Morning Herald the men were part of a group who had just left the hotel when the incident occurred, as they walked up Wigram Road.A third person was also assaulted during the incident, according to the publication. DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.content: A shooting that left one man dead and another seriously injured in Sydney's inner-city has been described by police as a "brazen and callous attack" and a targeted ambush.
